Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes several avenues of study relating the topology and geometry of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. The principal topics are the study of immersed surfaces in 3-manifolds, maps between hyperbolic 3-manifolds, and volumes of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. The most ambitious aspect of the project involves the virtual Haken conjecture, which is equivalent to showing that hyperbolic 3-manifolds have a finite-sheeted cover which contains an embedded pi_1-injective surface. The PI would like to relate this to the virtual fibering conjecture of Thurston, which states that a hyperbolic 3-manifold has a finite-sheeted cover which fibers over the circle, and implies the virtual Haken conjecture. The PI would like to show that Haken 3-manifolds are homotopy equivalent to a compact CAT(0) cube complex. Next, the PI would like to show that fundamental groups of hyperbolic 3-manifolds are LERF. This would follow if Gromov-hyperbolic groups are residually finite, although this is believed to be false by many geometric group theorists. Following a program of Haglund and Wise, these conjectures would imply that a Haken hyperbolic manifold has fundamental group which virtually embeds in a right-angled reflection group. This in turn would imply that these manifolds virtually fiber by previous work of the PI. The PI also plans to investigate the volumes of hyperbolic Haken manifolds, and how various topological restrictions on the manifold give rise to lower bounds on volume. For example, the PI would like to understand the asymptotic behavior of the volumes of orientable hyperbolic 3-manifolds with n cusps.


The mathematical study of 3-dimensional spaces goes back to the work of Poincare. Because classical physics describes our universe to be a 3-dimensional space, the classification of 3-dimensional spaces is an important mathematical endeavor, since it may have ramifications for the global structure of our universe. Recently, this classification was spectacularly achieved by Perelman, using Hamilton's Ricci flow, who resolved Thurston's geometrization conjecture, and as a consequence the Poincare conjecture, which goes back 100 years. The geometrization conjecture implies that any finite 3-dimensional space has a canonical decomposition into geometric pieces, the most interesting of which are hyperbolic 3-manifolds. Mathematicians studying 3-manifolds are still sorting out the implications of Perelman's work and of the geometrization conjecture. This project will pursue various aspects of the ramifications of the geometrization conjecture. The principal and most ambitious project will study 2-dimensional objects inside of 3-dimensional spaces, especially the hyperbolic ones, which satisfy certain strong topological restrictions. Studying these 2-dimensional objects has implications for the global structure of finite 3-dimensional spaces. The project also aims to study the geometry of hyperbolic 3-manifolds, and in particular understand the simplest such manifolds and how their geometric properties (such as volume) relate to their topological properties, such as how many components of the boundary.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of 3-dimensional spaces is an active area of mathematics research. Thurston conjectured that all compact 3-dimensional spaces have a canonical decomposition into geometric pieces, and his conjecture was resolved by Perelman in the last decade. The most important of these geometries is hyperbolic geometry. In 1982, Thurston wrote an expository article outlining his understanding of hyperbolic 3-dimensional spaces. At the end of the article, he made a list of 24 problems which have guided research in the field for the last 30 years. During the last decade, most of the remaining problems in this list have been resolved (an important outstanding problem due to Milnor has seen essentially no progress), including the Ahlfors Measure Conjecture, Marden's Tameness Conjecture, the Ending Lamination Conjecture, and the Geometrization Conjecture. After the resolution of these conjectures, the most important remaining problems involved the study of ``virtual" properties of 3-manifolds, referring to finite-sheeted covers. Waldhausen had proposed in 1968 that certain 3-manifolds have finite-sheeted covers which are "Haken", containing an essential 2-dimensional surface inside them, the Virtual Haken Conjecture. Another problem of Thurston was the Virtual Fibering Conjecture, that hyperbolic 3-manifolds have a finite-sheeted cover which is obtained as a mapping torus of a surface. This has turned out to be an important question, since it can factor 3-dimensional problems into the study of surfaces and their automorphisms. 

Recently we resolved the Virtual Haken Conjecture (including 4 remaining problems in Thurston's list), following a program of Dani Wise. In fact, the resolution made use of work of Kahn and Markovic constructing immersed essential surfaces in hyperbolic 3-manifolds, for which they received the Clay Research Award in 2012. Several other contributions to this program were made by Wise's collaborators Bergeron, Haglund, Hsu and Sageev, and by Agol's collaborators Groves and Manning. The techniques make use of Gromov's notion of hyperbolic groups and CAT(0) cube complexes, and the notion of relatively hyperbolic Dehn filling. Somehow to prove a result about 3-manifolds, one has to first pass to a larger category of high-dimensional cube complexes in which flabby 3-dimensional objects become rigid and crystalline. Although the result is more general, it makes use of some ideas originating in 3-manifold theory, including hierarchies and hyperbolic Dehn filling. The full resolution of this conjecture represents hundreds of pages of mathematics, of which we have made just the final contribution, representing a maturation of Gromov's perspective on the geometry of groups. Also, this project completes the main component of the NSF proposal for this grant. 

Agol's student Yi Liu has been partially supported by this grant, and has made important contributions to the study of maps between 3-manifolds, among other things, including the resolution of conjectures of Simon and Rong.
